reviewText:
Just completed the game. Took about 10 hours from start to finish, though I restarted at one point so my whole playtime was longer.

Short version: I liked it. It’s got a nice visual style. It falls somewhere in between a casual game and one of those that takes forever to learn and takes over your lfe. It's definitely more complex, difficult and well-made than a casual game. I was impressed by the way everything was presented in a very accessible way, despite the mechanics actually being fairly involved. I wouldn't replay it (mostly because there doesn't seem to be much else to uncover), but thought it was great while it lasted. It's actually harder in the first half than after (basically once you’ve unlocked all the research it gets a lot easier, probably a little too easy). Even still, the developers still have a few tricks up their sleeves to keep things interesting at that point.

Basic Premise
In Dead in Bermuda, you control eight characters who are stranded on a Bermuda island after a plane crash. You assign each person two tasks each day, collect and use resources, and manage their various maladies. The goal is to survive, explore the island and find a way off it. The characters each have vastly different stat attributes and various relationships with one another (there’s a husband and wife, father and daughter pair, etc.).

For the most part, this is a management-style game. To a smaller extent, there are small quests, dialog, but much of this is pretty linear, so you have limited control over it. There's also some plot twists that may come up also that complicate things a bit, once you're further into the game.

Gameplay
Your main points of concern are: their stats/skills, their maladies (fatigue, hunger, depression, sickness, injury), their resources, and relationships. Their stats, skills, maladies, relationships with each other are all interrelated and correlated in various ways and impact their effectiveness at tasks. Managing these elements is at the heart of the game, and striking a good, complex balance is what the game does really well.

To survive, you need to manage their maladies – if any reach 100%, that character dies. Ideally, you want to leave the island with everyone! As you research, you will gain access to new tasks which give you access to new resources or easier ways to produce certain resources. Meanwhile, you're also exploring the island, which consists of 100 plots, which nets you resources and sends you off on various quests. The quests are pretty simple and don't significantly affect gameplay, but I thought they were fun, and you meet some colorful characters.

One big plus for me was how the main points of concern shifts as the game progresses. For example, at first, finding food is your main problem to contend with. However, very quickly, you notice your sicknesses are building up and things you were ignoring before might kill you. (Which is why I had to restart, haha) But as soon as you sort that out, then other concerns take over, etc. Kept me on my toes.

To win the game, you need to explore the island, and I won’t give away the rest, but let’s just say yes there's a way off the island. In terms of strategy, it doesn’t have a huge effect, but it brings some variety into the mix.

Difficulty
I would say that this game is much harder and more interesting in the beginning half than the ending half. The hardest part is staying alive the first 15-20 days. Since you have limited access to resources, you have to be very strategic. I loved the first half of this game. Thought it was delightful and interesting and a very healthy level of difficulty. It’s well-paced and well-designed.

The second half or so, for me somewhere around 50 days in I think, gets a little tedious once you have researched everything and have consistent access to all resources. The quests provide some entertainment to get you through it. (The plot twists are also thrown in there, which may impact your strategy as well, but they involve a little more guesswork than I'd prefer. Not my favorite aspect of the game.)

Replayability
There’s not much variation from game to game, apart from some randomness in the locations of occurrences when exploring the island and personality modifiers for the characters. As far as I can tell, there’s no new content that I’m missing out on by not replaying it, so I think the replay value is pretty low. I wish there were at least alternate endings depending on how quickly you finish the game or something, but whatever.

Overall
Overall, I really enjoyed the game, even if it was a little of a grind towards the end. For me, it hit a sweet spot of being both strategically complex and also accessible. Even though I would not replay it, I thought it was well worth my time and money. Definitely one of the better games I've played in a while.

reviewText:
Dead in Bermuda is a Survival/Management game, where you the player get to control 8 survivors who are stranded on a island because their plane crashed. I know what your thinking, another survival game. But i can tell you that this game is far different from all those other out there, and that’s a good thing.

Dead in Bermuda does a lot of things different, for instance you get to keep not one person alive, but eight. And that is where the management aspect of the game comes to live. Each character has their own stats on what they are good at, and what they are not so good at. Sending out a character with the scavenging skill out to explorer, will not give you the best results obviously. So you need to be careful on where you send your survivors to. There is also a bit of a RPG style to it, as you can also level up your characters during your play session, and increase their skills.

There are a couple of things you can do during a single day. each day allows you to take 2 actions for each character. During the morning you can send people out to scavenge food, wood etc. And then again during the mid-day. So each part of the day takes a turn. Setting your priorities is very important in such a game. During the evening you get to divide the food for the entire party. And i really love how they did this, because with a lot of these survival games, a character takes a absurd amount of food needed to survive. in this game they are very happy with a normal single meal. You have different choices on what to give each person. a small meal which brings the hunger bar down to 10% to 20% or a bigger meal that does 20% to 40%. There are also smaller bite size snacks that will help with the lower percentage hunger. But in my opinion this is a very cool and realistic method. Obviously if you do not feed them, their hunger bar will rise higher and they will then need more food to survive.

Your goal in this game is of course to survive as long as possible and while doing so you get to research items and craft them for your base or for your exploration missions. Having people explorer the island you are on will reveal new locations where you can find items and other things to interact with.  Besides the normal stat bars, your characters also have other bars that need your attention, cause it’s survival game, so not all happy times. For instances you got to keep track of their fatigue when they are doing tasks. Their depression bar, which goes up when they see dead bodies or other party members talking bad stuff about them. But having a rest and let them talk to other people in the group will lower those bars again. I could go very in dept in to the stats and bars, but i am sure you get the point to it. keep the bad stats down, and increase the good stats. Another thing i just mentioned i really like about this game, is the interaction the susrvivors have with each other. You really get to learn who they are, and what is on their minds. A story is being told as you play a long. And that is something you do not often see in such games.

Another thing about this game that stands out is the graphics style. A 2D hand painted look, which looks beautiful in my opinion. Also the music in this game is very soothing to listen to, from relaxing moments, to the more intense ones. It really captures you in that moment.

But don’t get me wrong, while it looks beautiful and seems easy enough by my comments about it, it is a pretty difficult game as well. My first couple of play through i reached around day 13 and 15 before everyone died. Well who knew you would need water to survive. So a lot of trial and error here. But it is very worth it to play it again and again, because every day something new can and will happen. From what i could tell so far it has a lot of replay value.

For me personally this has been one of the most surprising games to come out this year, and i can full heartedly recommend this game to anyone, especially if you are into survival or management games.

reviewText:
Try the demo!

Extremely nice to see game developers actually letting people play the first 5 days of their game.  It lets you see exactly how it plays.  The game becomes more complicated and difficult past those first 5 days too.  The game is clearly pitched at the survival aspect, but the social management side is well developed and interesting as well.  I feel like I am watching the first few episodes of Lost as I play the game, solving small problems, dealing with clashing personalities and figuring out what everyone is good at.  Then of course you will eventually lose someone, probably, and you have to learn how to survive without their expertise.

Don't forget to use your items, I have absolutely been saved by them.  Make sure you keep up with all the actions, maybe you will research a book which shows you how to solve your current shortcoming, or maybe you will find a location in the jungle that happens to have the very resource you need.  You can get your group in a holding pattern and stabilise, but eventually you will have a lack which forces you to move on or perish.

Lastly, I feel like the game is replayable.  You can work with your people a different way, or perhaps try to explore a different stretch of terrain earlier, or approach an unexpected encoutner differently.  It certainly is not infinitely repeatable, but I will certainly get a second playthrough and perhaps even a third out of this game.


I have only encountered a single bug so far.  After a character in my camp died, they no longer showed up at the evening conversation, but the others would still refer to them as if they were still alive.  A small bug, but a little immersion breaking.

Either way, I still very much recommend this game if you liked Lost or would like a slower, more relaxed survival and social puzzle.  Everything is turn based, so you can think about what you want to do.

Dead in Bermuda is like what if Lost and Gods will be Watching had a baby together. After a mysterious plane crash you are left with 8 survivors and must do everything in your power to stay alive. Balancing hunger, depression, injury, sickness, and more. On top of that you have social aspects such as love or people getting on each others nerves. There are things to help you through your journey of the island. Each survivor comes with a set of skills and specialties, that can be applied to multiple tasks such as crafting, hunting, gathering, exploring, researching and more. Survivors may be good at certain skills and terrible in other skills, each character is different and many elements to this are also randomized per playthrough. If you love management there is plenty to enjoy in those aspects, on the other hand if you love a mystery and story that progresses at your own pace then exploring the island is amazing fun. This is where Dead in Bermuda truly shines and where it truly immersed me in the world.  Where most games go for a super realistic tone, Dead in Bermuda doesn't mind straying into the supernatural. Aside from there are many things to enjoy here, leveling/skill system, great replay value, love interests, randomized environment, and plenty of Gilligan's Island shenanigans. The graphics are simple but have their own unique tone and flavor, there are times that I felt it reminded me of a bit of a visual novel.  One minor complaint is that moving 8 characters about by dragging them across the screen became tedious however, this is a minor complaint. In all I really enjoyed Dead in Bermuda and encourage you to explore the island...or else.

reviewText:
Dead in Bermuda is an 2D indie survival strategy game with an excellent look and entertaining gameplay.
If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.

What is happening in the game:Eight survivors have landed on a desert island and have to use their best skills to survive. You have to take care of they fatigue, depression, injuries and other stats. You have to last as long as possible with as many characters you can save until maybe, one day, the rescue ship comes by and picks your people out.

Pros:    Graphics | The first thing I noticed was the way this game looks and, damn, it looks attractive! All of the characters look great and their looks fit the way they behave. Also, there are many parts of land you can discover and each of them has a wonderful enviroment.
Complex Character Mechanics | Each one of the characters has his own skill stats, such as scavenging, crafting, fishing and so on. Everyone even has stats for how well do they get along with everyone else. Pretty cool.
Island Exploration | Although the tough part of the game is taking care of and arranging characters to make sure they even live, you also get to explore the island you're on. Each turn, you can research one square of the island and find what's on it. You can make actions to this finding, such as search it for goods, disassemble it and others. When you do that, you have to pick a character. Each of them has a stealth skill. The stealthier he is, the smaller the chance is to get attacked.
Tutorial | Although the game is quite simple to understand, the tutorial comes in handy and gives you a few useful tips. This is really good if it's your first time playing.
Checkpoints and Saving | Not only that the game autosaves, it also keeps previous saves. This means you can revert back in case you made some poor choices.
Randomisation | Every time you start a new game, skills, items, relationships and even the island are reset. This means big replayability, which is great with survival games.
The Soundtrack | This game is accompanied by some great atmospheric music and it's really well-made. I couldn't find out who made the tracks, but I would love to see a Soundtrack DLC!
Steam Integration | As you would expect, there are Trading Cards and Achievements.
Cons:    A Few Bugs | The first time I started the game, I encountered a bug that wouldn't let me start a new game. As it turns out, I was not the only one with the same problem, but the developers can't figure out what's wrong. However, this problem is solved after a couple of game resets or maybe reinstalls, so it's not a big deal.
Lack of OS Support | You would expect to see at least Linux support since SteamOS is getting more and more popular. Nuh uh. WIndows only.
The final verdict:Yes, yes, and yes. I'm not a big fan of survival games, but this one definitely hits the right spot. The atmosphere is great, the gameplay simple yet challenging and, last but not least, the way all of the characters behave. You have to take care of each one of them and it takes a great deal of skill and persistence to help them survive.
If you're a fan of survival games, this should be an insta-buy for you. If you're not, you should still consider this.

This game is pretty fun and makes good use of RPG and survival elements.  The RPG aspect allows you to level up your survivors and shape them up to cover up their weaknesses or augment their strengths.  The survival management gives you the tough choices of whether you should feed one person over another or scavenge for supplies or get them to explore a new location possibly yielding more bounty or nothing at all.  All of this while managing the hunger, depression, injury and even relationships of all 8 of your survivors.

One of the game's few flaws is that it is fairly easy and you will probably beat it after your first or second playthrough. You will find that relationships are random and whether or not it increases or decreases when they work together is up to RNG.  Replayability is somewhat there with them being assigned different traits and locations on the island with each playthrough, however you will end up using them the same way as you did before because they all begin with the same stats as before.

Given that for 10+ hours I couldn't stop playing this game. This game receives a thumbs up.  Just don't go in thinking that this game can be played for hours upon hours on end.

Summary: This is a beautiful game resource management/worker placement game that has high aesthetic appeal and really engaging characters that do draw you into a island world. The game hits the mark on many levels of design but the core elements of the gameplay are riddled with an overwhelming number of dice rolls and convoluted algorithms that ruin an otherwise simple game.

Dead in Bermuda hits alot of things that makes this a very visually appealing game. The parallax style that it uses in almost of it elements gives it a very unique style and overall visual approach that you don't find anymore. Compared to many other games of this genre finding a game with a moderen design is really rare.

Another high point is the dialogue between the characters. While the main story may be dry, the 8 characters each have very distinct personalities that play very well off of each other. You don't really care where this characters are going you just want to see them interact. It's more like a drama with no plot but still a more engaging than some other games.

I was draw to this game for two reason. One; I love worker placement games, mostly board games, because it's hard to find this genre in video games. Two; I'm really in love with its visual design, because I'm a graphic design student. After playing the game I was met with a large amount of disappointment. One of the appeals of this genre is that RNG or dice rolls is kept to a minimum. Bead In Bermuda has so many dice rolls even a DnD player would roll their eyes.

Each character  5 states that you must monitor and keep as low as possible as if one fills that character dies, and also 16 stats that detemine their effectiviness in a certain action or the ability to resist state changes or to recover from state changes. The 16 stats are pretty munch sismply to old school western style rpg design, but what's different is that each skill will raise in level as you use it. This makes no sense in this style of game as you will be so stressed for resources you will need people to what their best at not what thier worst at to skill farm, beacuse of that having skills raise in level seems pointless.

But then again performing any actions seems pointless when having a higher skill level barely raises your min. value. Yes, the first to raise is your max value, not your min. value. Exampe, the fishing action will show 0-8 as a possible outcome. Meaning it is still possible to get 0 fisth despite the fact your fishing skill is 100. Meaning for most actions raising skills ls like instead of rolling a 1d4 you get to roll 1d8 instead. Now if  you're unlucky like me then you rolled in the lower bracket pretty much everytime. It just doesn't make sense. Similarly, the relationship between the states and the stats doesn't make sense. Fatigue lowers your condition, but you need condition to lower your fatigue. There are many instances where this happens and honestly it should happen in this genre of game where you get into an uphill battle but it happens way too soon and just turns into a lockdown for any character that has too low condition. Namely this happens because as with gaining fatigue to lose the fatigue you have to roll for it. Not to mention you gain fatigue even when you sleep at night, also  determined by another dice roll. The pentalies for having high states just becomes so high that if a character gets  3 or more states to even 40% at the same time they are basicly just marked for death as they will have no way to recover from that unless you use an item, which don't appear alot.

I wanted to love this game but having dice determine literally everthing makes it feel like I'm not really doing anything and that I'm losing not because of my bad choices. As for turning it to easy mode it because so easy it was basicly a just a waste of time. This game in its current state, as I have read it has changed, is basicly more like a punishment game for people that love survival games and staring RNG in the face.

I played another game like this before about people lost on an island which I enjoyed very much, so I was excited to hear about this one. Nice hand drawn art style

Fitting music and sound

An interesting back story that is somewhat Lost-ish

The game starts out very easy with a short learning curve (some have said it's a long learning curve, but if you spend about a half hour reading all of the tutorial tips it's really not that bad) and then continues to get harder day by day

Very addictive

A large island to explore

The island locations are randomly placed with each game

An impressive RPG-like skill tree

The devs seem dedicated to keeping the game updated

The cons:

Like most games of this style it can become a bit repetitious after a while as to be expected

Sometimes food can be a little to scarce after about 2 weeks making the game very hard, but I hear the devs are making an easy mode.

I have not played all the way to the end yet, but I figure the replay value cannot be to high for a game like this once you know the story.

The English is a bit broken and you will find a few grammatical errors from time to time, but nothing to harsh.



All in all, I would say this game is worth the money if you are a fan of casual RPG-like simulation strategy games.

reviewText:
Story:
After an air crash on an island 8 survivors try to survive and find a way to get off the island. All characters greatly differ from each other. You have a guy who thinks to know how to survive on the island not being very likeable for the most of the people, as well as a bookworm who survived the plane crash with her father and stepmother, having a strong relationship with her father and apparently not having much normal fun in her life so far, another on is an agent who believes a spy is among the survivors and so forth.
The game has a unique way to convey the story. At night, before distributing the rations, a dialogue (which may influence the needs and relationships of the characters) triggers, depending on what happened the day, who worked with whom, what was discovered on the island and so on, what kind of means that you won’t have the exact same dialogues on each of your playthroughs. You get to know the characters and their relationships better. I really liked that part and it feels like the characters truly are different personalities.

Gameplay:
You have to manage the castaways on their daily life on the island. They need to collect resources, craft as well as research new buildings. But that’s not all. Considering the needs of every single survivor is much more important which are as follows: depression, injury, hunger, fatigue and sickness. Neither of these must become 100% as the character die hence. Though the game isn’t over when a character dies, it becomes just harder as there is one person less to help around the camp.
The characters have relationships with each other which influence the efficiency of the activities the survivor do together. So if two gather resources together and don’t like each other (relationships increase/decrease when working together) they’ll find less resources in contrast to two who like each other, having the same needed skills as the first two. Talking about skills, there are 16 skills which are diverse on each character. Some cook better, scavenge better, are better at exploring the island and et cetera. Due to that you have to think about who should do what. Should somebody with a high skill do the job, resulting in a high outcome or can you afford to place somebody less skilled there (becoming better after a while of course) so that the other one can rest for awhile or perhaps another crucial activity? All characters increase their skills by perform the corresponding job. And after a few skill increases the characters levels up and receive skill points which can be used to improve the individual skills.

Graphic/aesthetic:
Everything is beautiful drawn and the game has its’ own style, a bit cartoonish but still realistic enough to convey the characters and the environments.

If you are now interested in the game, you should give the demo a try. It’s only a few days long but I think that’s sufficient to get to know if the game is for you and the savegame can be used in the main game too. The price is very low compared to the quality by the way and the developers still listen to customers suggestions (at least when this review was written ;)).

reviewText:
Dead In Bermuda is a survival management game with some rudimentary RPG elements. The premise of this game is very simple - a plane has crashed, with only eight survivors and your goal is to survive and escape the mysterious island.
Each survivors characteristics are predetermined. In other cases, lack of customization can be viewed as a flaw, but these characters are designed excellently. There is your typical big brawny Russian guy Yuri, the middle aged couple whose strengths are cooking and fishing and of course the guy who goes completely nuts and so on.
Gameplay is very straightforward. Every day is split up into three turns: sunrise, sunset and nighttime. In first two you manage resources like wood, water, food etc. by scavenging, gathering and exploring. You can also research and craft new constructions, which will help you to gather resources more efficiently. Besides various resources, you also manage survivors health like sickness and injuries, hunger, depression and more. If one of the statuses hits 100, the survivor is dead. In nighttime your survivors will have conversations, which will change their opinion about each other, increase or decrease their depression accordingly.
The simplicity of the gameplay can be mistaken for its low difficulty or others even say that this game is casual, but I strongly disagree. It’s not casual but rather laid back, because it’s turn based and doesn’t have any action in its classical sense. Also in my first playthrough I found it quite difficult, but on the second one, yes, it was very easy. (On replayability I will touch upon later)
Story. By exploring you meet other people (?) who are also stranded on the island. By having conversations and doing tasks for them you unravel the mystery and by completing the last “mission” the truth is reviled and you escape the island (or do you?).
The story is captivating but very predictable and quite shallow and reminds me of the TV show Lost. After meeting the first two NPCs I already understood what they are and what the island is all about and the endings plot twist wasn’t “twisty” at all. But I am more of a gameplay person rather than story one (at least in these kind of games), so it really didn’t take away from my enjoyment of the game.
Aesthetic. In my opinion, the game looks sooooo pretty, because I very much like this cartoony, hand drawn look, but that’s very subjective matter. The one thing I can criticize is the music. The background music is very monotonous, you get sick of it in five minutes, and because there is no voice acting, I just listened to my music, which I do very rarely while playing a video game. I think this game could be improved a lot if the dialog would be voice acted, because it is actually very well written, it’s witty, provoking, sad and even depressing at times.
Replayability.  This is the games biggest flaw, for me. If I like a geme, and I certainly liked this one, I want to replay it multiple times. BUT the game has very low or even no replay value. Because it is linear, there is one or very few optimal ways to complete it and there is only one ending. Usually games will have different endings depending on how many and which people will survive but this game has only one. After playing it for 14h and completing it twice, I have no desire to go back. If they add new content I will definitely play it again, but it seem not very likely because game feel very polished and complete.
My final verdict is that I recommend Dead In Bermuda if you like management games with superb management mechanics and don’t mind spending 15EUR on a game you will play for max 15h.

reviewText:
Dead in Bermuda is a management sim with RPG elements in which you try to help a group of strangers survive in the aftermath of a plane crash on a remote island. Their survival hinges on your ability to properly utilize their skills, monitor their mental and physical well-being, and stave off any homicidal interactions.

I tend to enjoy management games and RPGs, and I was pleased to find that their marriage worked pretty well in this case. I found the management aspect to be pretty challenging at first—my first couple attempts ended with everyone dying of either hunger or sickness—but since figuring out how to survive is the point of the game, I think it was appropriately difficult and the challenge added to my overall enjoyment. I also thought that the characters were generally well done: everyone has a pretty distinct personality, and everyone’s character is revealed and developed fairly naturally using conversation around the campfire at the end of each day.

I do have a couple nitpicks with the game, however. I understand that this game was translated from another language, but despite an English proofreader being listed in the credits, there are still enough errors to merit another pass at proofreading. Pretty minor stuff, admittedly—awkward phrasing, incorrect capitalization, etc.—but still not something that should be present in a complete retail product. Another issue is the limited dialogue pool. I mentioned earlier that I thought the campfire conversation was well done, but there just isn’t enough of it. I’ve played through the game twice now, and the significant overlap in dialogue events that I saw does nothing to encourage me to play through the game a third time. Finally, the mid to late game is pretty boring. (And I’m saying this post-patch 1.1, after they apparently tried to address this.) Once your survival situation has stabilized, you end up just passing the days until you’ve explored enough of the island to end the game. I actually think that this is a symptom of having made the island too large: I bet if the devs made exploration easier (so island areas were revealed more quickly) but reduced the number of helpful areas, the game would retain its difficulty in the beginning without dragging at the end.

Despite my criticisms, I enjoyed figuring out how to help these people survive (sometimes despite themselves). I can see this game appealing to other casual management sim fans who don’t mind failing a few times while figuring out what to do.
